title: Luxury Collection fetes expansion plans with new US, European properties
text:
August 11, 2015 Breakfast at The Palace, a Luxury Collection Hotel, San Francisco 
Starwood Hotels & Resorts’ The Luxury Collection has updated its North American and European portfolio through a series of hotel openings and massive restorations. 
Travel trends are fluid and consumer surveys, such as Travel + Leisure’s World’s Best Awards 2015 ( see story ), track the progression of travelers’ interests and where their global itineraries are taking them. In turn, high-end hospitality brands must operate and maintain properties in areas frequented by affluent travelers, as well as expand their portfolios to uncharted destinations as to stay fresh. 
Book a stay In the United States, Luxury Collection is promoting three of its properties, two of which just recently underwent intensive renovations and the third being a brand new hotel. 
Hotel Ivy in Minneapolis reopened on July 29 after a multi-million dollar transformation which includes enhanced guest rooms and suites, a street-level bar and lounge and a subterranean bar offering a twist on traditional cocktails. The Palace, a Luxury Collection Hotel in San Francisco, also underwent multi-phase restorations that returned the property to its 1875 grandeur through updated guest rooms, pool and fitness center and public spaces. 
Debuting in the U.S. is The St. Anthony in San Antonio, TX. Debuting in October 2015, the hotel, originally built in 1909, will immerse guests in a bygone era through its accommodations and public places, all of which pay homage to its cultural heritage. 
The St. Anthony, a Luxury Collection Hotel, San Antonio 
Starwood’s The Luxury Collection is converting and renovating a slew of properties across North America to rejuvenate the brand. 
The brand is on pace to surpass 100 hotels in more than 30 countries by the end of this year. To ensure that the brand’s core properties safeguard The Luxury Collection’s value proposition, a major infusion of funds will go to the improvement of North American hotels ( see story ). 
Also new to Luxury Collection’s European portfolio as of this summer is the Augustine in Prague featuring 100 guest rooms and suites spread among seven historic buildings including a 13th century monastery and Caresse in Bodrum, Turkey with 84 rooms overlooking the bay. The expansion in Europe also includes Falisia in Portopiccolo, Italy, a resort set along the Adriatic coast and the Grand Hotel River Park in Bratislava, Slovakia at the heart of the city’s development project. 
Caresse, a Luxury Collection Resort & Spa, Bodrum, Turkey 
Additionally, Luxury Collection opened the Grand Mansion, a hotel with 158 guestrooms just steps from the Presidential Palace in Nanjing, China, in July.
